title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Best Buds on the market
author: Andrew Gross
content: The Google Pixel Buds are an absolute game-changer in the world of wireless earbuds. From the moment I put them on, I was blown away by the exceptional sound quality. The audio is crisp, clear, and the bass packs a punch. Whether I'm listening to music, podcasts, or taking calls, the audio experience is consistently top-notch.Battery life is a crucial factor for any wireless earbuds, and the Pixel Buds deliver in this department. I've been using them for hours on end, and the long-lasting battery life is impressive. No more constantly worrying about recharging them, which is a significant convenience.The noise-cancelling feature is, in a word, perfect. It effortlessly blocks out ambient noise, allowing me to immerse myself fully in my music or conversations without any distractions. It's a game-changer for my daily commute and working in noisy environments.The design is sleek and comfortable to wear for extended periods. The touch controls are intuitive and responsive, adding to the overall user experience. The connectivity is seamless, and they pair effortlessly with my devices.In conclusion, the Google Pixel Buds are a true masterpiece of wireless earbud technology. The amazing sound quality, long-lasting battery life, and perfect noise cancelling make them an unbeatable choice. They've quickly become an integral part of my daily life, and I couldn't be happier with my purchase. Highly recommended! ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Wireless Showdown: Pixel Buds in the Ring
author: Heather A. Turner
content: Venturing into the realm of the Google Pixel Buds, I embarked on a journey of exploration that spanned across platforms, including iPhone and Windows computer usage. This review aims to offer a comprehensive perspective on the capabilities of these wireless earbuds, in comparison to other popular options. To be honest I tried them out because they were on supersale during Prime Day. So why not!The Pixel Buds shine brightly in several aspects. Their design, minimalistic and comfortable, ensures a snug fit suitable for both workouts and daily activities. The sound quality, characterized by crisp audio and punchy bass, impressed me across a variety of musical genres. Google's adaptive sound feature, dynamically adjusting volume based on surroundings, further enhanced the listening experience.As an iPhone user I love Airpods but they are pretty pricey. Speaking of alternatives, let's talk about the AirPods. The Pixel Buds stack up well in terms of sound quality and the real-time translation feature, giving them a distinct edge. I have found the battery to be pretty good and have not had to recharge nearly as often as my Airpod Pros.Considering the AirPods, while they integrate seamlessly with Apple devices, the Pixel Buds' compatibility with different platforms is a plus. Additionally, the Pixel Buds' noise canceling and translation capabilities broaden their appeal beyond audio quality alone.To sum it up, the Google Pixel Buds offer a solid package. Their design, audio quality, and innovative features position them as strong contenders in the wireless earbud market. Though a few minor drawbacks exist, they deliver an enjoyable audio journey. Whether you lean towards the Google ecosystem or seek versatile wireless earbuds with modern touches, the Pixel Buds are well worth your consideration. So I say, if they are on SUPERSALE give them a spin!

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Middle-of-the-road earbuds in a small case
author: Dave Gilbert
content: I had high hopes for these given the brand reputation - Beats are a well-established partner for Apple and are supposed to be good for listening to music. Beats are known to be particularly good for bass-heavy music; I have a pair of Beats over ear headphones and they are decent. These earbuds however do not live up to the reputation.Pros:* I was excited to see how small the case is for these earphones. It is significantly smaller and lighter than the typical Apple airpods case, for example. I ordered in the translucent red and it is a cool look. I like being able to see the electronics within the case (the buds are solid color red).* the form factor and related design of the buds is excellent. They are covered in a rubberized material typical for sports electronics, making them water and sweat resistant as well as mostly impervious to dirt. the fit in the ear is really good, and they come with multiple sets of ear tips in matching color. They do not fall out of my ear despite use during sports / exercise.* sound quality for phone use is very good. I can hear well and callers can hear me. They hold up to reasonable background noise.* sound quality for podcasts and other spoken word is also good. I can hear clearly and volume is sufficient.* iphone integration is decent. The earbud controls appear on iphone in a similar fashion to airpods.* battery life is good. I would estimate 10-12 hrs on a single charge.* they come with a 1-year warrranty from Apple (as documented in the product guide)Cons:*sound quality with music is only so-so. I was frankly disapointed. They do not hold up well in an A-B comparison with my Apple Airpod Pros (2nd generation) - a decent Mid-Fi option. In my opinion these are unsuitable for listening to music.* no case battery. The reason the case is so much smaller is because the case itself cannot charge the ear buds without being plugged in. I guess this is ok since the battery life on the ear buds is very good compared with others, but it was a surprise to me.* missing my favorite airpod feature - automatic pause. On my airpods, if I take one out of my ear the source pauses. Seems like a missed opportunity given the existing integration.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 2, 2024

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Beats Solo Buds: Compact Sound Titans in a Budget-Friendly Package
author: JAYSIN
content: The Beats Solo Buds are a testament to the brand's **continued attention to sound quality**, delivering an auditory experience that impresses at its price point. While they may lack a battery within the case, reducing the overall listening time, the buds themselves offer an **excellent battery life**. In testing, they lasted just shy of **17.5 hours**, though individual results may vary slightly. Their portability is a significant advantage, making them a convenient choice for on-the-go music enthusiasts.It's true, the absence of an **IP rating** for water and sweat resistance, along with the lack of noise canceling or spatial audio features, might be seen as downsides. However, these omissions are somewhat mitigated by the buds' affordability. The removal of the indicator light, a seemingly small feature we've all come to rely on, is a curious choice by Apple. It's akin to a phone without a camera; it functions, but something feels amiss. Now, users must rely on their phones to check the battery life and confirm if the charging cable is properly connected. For iPhone users, this information is conveniently displayed via an on-screen card, while Android users can find it in the app.Despite these quirks, the Beats Solo Buds strike a balance between **size, sound quality, and price** that many will find just right. For those seeking alternatives, the Soundcore Space A40 offers a similar size, more overall battery life, a wireless charging case, and comparable sound quality with a bit more sub-bass impact. They also boast a comfortable fit with ANC and an actual **IPX4 rating**, all at a price point that's often under $50 on sale, available in black, blue, and white‚Äîall of which are quite stylish. Ultimately, the Beats Solo Buds stand out for their portability and sound quality, making them a worthy consideration for those prioritizing these features within this price range.

title: 1.0 out of 5 stars Mediocre sound; lacking features; works with iPhone
author: Anne Swan
content: This is a very disappointing product from Beats. I've had the fantastic Power Beats Pro ear buds with ear hooks and lots of features for a couple years, so I expected more from this product--even at the low price point. First, the positive features: they were easy to pair with my iPhone 15 Pro Max. They also came with some charge; they do hold a charge for a long time and charge up quickly. The built in microphone worked for phone calls. The best feature was that the XS ear tips fit my small ear canal; I've not ever had an ear bud type that actually staying in my ear before--a first! The translucent red case and the red earbuds are attractive. The small case is portable, but frankly, I have no problem taking my slightly larger Power Beats Pro case anywhere I need it.Now, for the other aspects: The "selling" feature of this is its small size. Frankly, it makes it harder to maneuver, to get the buds out of the case and into ears. But most importantly, the sound is mediocre or less. There is no noise cancelling, and for some reason I have the volume setting on my iPhone turned as high as it will go and the sound on the earbud is at a low volume. Why won't the volume increase as typical speakers or headphones? Turns out I need some unnamed app to control the volume. But the instructions don't name the app. Also, I was unable to locate the app in the Apple App store. All I could find was an app for Beats Pill.As others have mentioned, the sound is in the high and mid-range--so the base is missing in the rock music and the classical music I prefer. I've had sound this "good" from cheap wired pairs. I would have liked some indication of which is right and left. The buds are very small, and I find it tricky to align them in the proper way to get them in the case. There is no noise cancelling feature; other offerings around this price point offer that. Also, this doesn't come with a cable or plug. I happen to have several USB-C cables and plugs, but if you don't have one, there's another expense. AIn my opinion, the positive features don't overcome the poor sound quality and the lack of noise cancelling. These do not make listening fun. I cannot recommend this product.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Apple/Beats is walking a middle line with these
author: This Is Not
content: I've been using these the last couple of days as my everyday drivers. I have tried Beats earbuds before, mainly the Studio Buds and the Studio Buds+. Neither stayed in my ears without relying on foam ear tips. So, I never fully switched to them and returned them for other products. I have a pair of old PowerBeats Pro, but I stopped using them a while back because they don't have ANC and rely on Lightning for charging (which should be a sin in 2024). I've always wanted to like the Studio Buds and Buds+ due to their design and overall solid build, but they never stayed in my ears.The same holds true with the Solo Buds. They're just like the Studio Buds+, just a little smaller and lighter. If the Studio Buds/Buds+ didn't stay in your ears, these ones won't either. I went through all the different ear tip sizes and medium fit me the best, but I had to push the right earbud back into my ear every hour or so.While I had these in my ears, I was able to do some listening. They popped up on my iPhone 15 Pro Max like all other Beats and Apple earbuds/headphones. You get some options in the iOS settings and the drop down menu. Unlike AirPods, these do not feature head tracking for spatial audio (though they do work with spatial audio, so does ANY pair of earbuds or headphones) or any ANC whatsoever. The charging case does not have a battery in it either. These earbuds last for about 17 hours (Apple advertises 18 hours) when I listened to them at about 75% volume.One thing that took me back was just how quiet these were. I had the same issue with the Studio Buds+. I have Soundcheck turned on in Apple Music due to listening to Atmos/Spatial tracks. It turns up their volume to match the volume of other tracks in my library while normalizing track volumes across the board. Still, I have other earbuds and headphones from Sony, Moondrop, and Heavys that don't require my iPhone's volume set to 75% for comfortable listening.Although the battery life is exceptional, charging these is a pain. Like I said, the case doesn't have a battery in it which means you need to be near a power source to recharge these. The case doesn't have a charging indicator light, so you don't know the charging state of the earbuds. Are they full, half, or somewhere between? I don't know, you need to lift their lid to find out. The bottom of the case is flat, just like Sony's case for their WF-1000XM5 earbuds (my everyday pair after I test others). It works for Sony because the case supports Qi charging. The Solo Buds case is begging to have a Qi charger in it. That would have helped immensely with the charging situation. Plop them on a Qi charger with an indicator light and wait for it to turn off. At least then you could tell when the earbuds were fully charged.But nope, Apple cut corners here and the case's only purpose is to take power from the back USB-C port and pipe it to the prongs connecting to the earbuds.Overall, the sound quality is fine, albeit very generic. Bass isn't boosted, neither are trebles. I would say this is a slight V-shaped curve, but not much. People expecting a bass boosted profile should know that these fit in the current Beats sound signature of things being flatter and more accurate. It's a little baffling given the history of Beats and that most people, especially those buying mainstream audio products, like a V-shaped sound signature with boosted lows and highs.I listened to modern pop, some metal, hard rock, and dubstep. It all sounded fine. Details were there, but not as much as my Sony WF-1000XM5. But I expected that given the price difference between these and the Sony earbuds (they MSRP for over 4X as much). There isn't wear detection or anything else fancy. Microphone quality is fine, it works but they do let in more outside noise than I'm used to. There isn't any special microphone noise cancelling like with other earbuds. If there is, I'm not hearing it.The biggest reason why I gave these 3 stars and not more is because, compared to other earbuds, these are far too expensive and should be in the $30 price range. Take the Soundcore A40 earbuds. They MSRP for $80 but are routinely on sale for $60 (sometimes even $50). They have less battery life, "only" 10 hours compared to 18. But that 10 hour battery life is while using ANC. It isn't the best ANC, but it's ANC nonetheless and that's something the Solo Buds do not have.The Soundcore A40 also have a companion app letting you adjust the EQ to your liking. It isn't an advanced EQ, but it's better than nothing and I think they sound much better than the Solo Buds. They aren't as quite and my iPhone sits at about 40-50% volume instead of 75% for comfortable listening (not even loud listening). The Soundcore A40 have a case featuring a battery and you can recharge the earbuds 4 more times. Their case also features Qi and USB-C charging with an indicator light. You know the rough battery percentage for the earbuds without popping the lid open. You can place the A40 case on a Qi charger and it will recharge both the case and earbuds without issues.For $20 less (right now), you can get a much better pair of earbuds from Soundcore/Anker that have more features and better sound quality. They don't have a fancy animation when you open them next to your iPhone or Android phone, but you get so much more out of them.Honestly, if Apple put a $30 price sticker on these, I would fully recommend them. You're getting neutral sounding earbuds with some smart features (mainly pairing and automatic spatial audio on iPhones). For $30, it's fine to miss a few features like wear detection and the lack of a battery in the charging case. But, at their current full MSRP (or even down to $50), these just aren't worth it, not for the compromises. If you really need to stick with the Beats brand, I think the Beats Flex are a better buy because they include an Apple chip (better iPhone compatibility) and you can put wing tips on them without ruining their compatibility with a charging case.I've also found the microphone quality to be better with the Beats Flex, it's probably because the microphone is closer to your mouth. I also think the Beats Flex sound better. They're still missing tons of smart features, but they're also often available for $50. They also have a charging indicator light.Honestly, I'm not sure what Apple was thinking with these at their full MSRP. You're paying for a little popup on your iPhone/Android and the Beats name, nothing more. Save money and go with Soundcore/Anker for better earbuds and an overall better package. Either that or, if you really want Beats, get the Beats Flex or wait for these to drop down to $35. They aren't worth more than that.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Top quality audio after a few adjustments
author: P. Dobrinen
content: This review is about the audio features of the JBL Vibe Beam earbuds.I'm an audio engineer so audio quality is very important to me. As such, I use wired connections as much as possible to maintain the integrity of the audio signal. However, many newer consumer-level products no longer have audio jacks, so I finally decided to invest in some wireless earbuds as a backup to the other earphones and headphones that I use. I didn't want to spend a lot of money as I didn't foresee myself using this product very much, and since this is my first foray into wireless audio earphones, if they were just ok or they broke after a while, then I wouldn't feel too bad about the little money that I spent. Also, I wanted to focus on finding wireless earbuds with excellent audio quality first as I already have an excellent high-end bluetooth earpiece for cell phone use, and I wouldn't be using this product as a bluetooth headset for my phone.After doing much research, I chose the JBL Vibe Beam's as they were at my price point, I'm familiar with JBL products, and I could reasonably expect that they were likely deliver the high audio quality that I've come to expect from JBL products. In my research, I read reviews that complained about the harshness of the high end with high frequency instruments like cymbals or the lack of bass, so I was a bit concerned.When I received and started listening to my JBL Vibe Beams I understood what people were talking about. However, to correct the issues, first, one must have a great fit of the earbuds in their ears. I'm fortunate, in that with the medium tips that were already installed on the Vibe Beams, they made a snug fit in my ears right out of the box. If you find that these earbuds do not fit well in your ears it might be worthwhile to invest in a separate set of variable sized earbud tips, or try tips from one of your other well-fitting earbuds, if you have them. Once the earbuds were seated properly in my ear, that took care of the poor bass issue. (I have not worn them long-term so I can't speak to them falling out of my ear, as others have mentioned, but they seem to stay in pretty well.)For the misaligned frequency response issue, fortunately, the JBL Headphone app that you can install on your cell phone includes a ten-band graphic equalizer that you can use to make adjustments to the frequency response of your earbuds. After listening to several of the reference tracks I use to check new audio equipment or my mixes against, I found that the only adjustments needed were carving out some of the upper midrange and making a very slight boost in the bottom end of the lower frequency spectrum. I've included a screenshot of my EQ curve which I based on the Bass preset in the JBL app. You can't tell as there is no dB scale on the side, but I needed to cut or boost by only 1-2 dB. I find that my new EQ curve gives a more balanced frequency response than what came out of the box, and matches up well against the reference speaker system and headphones that I use for my audio mixing and mastering work. I invite you to use my EQ curve as a starting point and adjust as sounds best to you.I also read reviews complaining about the apparent lack of volume of the Vibe Beams. I connected the JBL's to several different sources (phone, computer, TV, MP3 player, etc.) and I found that the overall maximum volume (with limiter off) is relatively lower than wired speaker versions. However, the input to the JBL's is relative to the maximum output of the source itself. I found that the loudest level I could get came from my iPhone and the lowest level output came from my MP3 player (which probably doesn't offer much output anyway being a tiny portable unit). As a comparison, I did a side-by-side test of the JBL's with my wife's AirPods (2nd gen). What I found was that the JBL's offered an almost identical audio output level as the AirPods with any of the sources I used so that confirmed that the output level of the JBL's has more to do with the source (and the source material as some songs are mastered at a lower volume than other songs) than with the earbuds themselves. During my test, I put the JBL's at their maximum volume output (one tap at a time on the left bud to raise the volume). Also, I noticed during my testing that the AirPods had a pleasing midrange sound perfect for listening to podcasts or watching video, but the JBL's excelled at full-range sound on the bottom and top ends of the frequency spectrum which made them sound much better over all and well-suited for music or listening to explosive action scenes in movies.And speaking of movies, the JBL app has a switchable audio/video mode. The video mode reduces the latency of the delivery of audio against picture, so there isn't a noticeable lip-sync issue with dialogue in a scene. However, there is a slight degradation in the audio quality of 'video' mode versus 'audio' mode, but you will have to make the determination if the change in audio quality is acceptable to you.As a side note, I included a picture of the inner side of the earbuds. The 'L' and 'R' designations on the earbuds are tiny as you can see, plus they are the same color as the earbuds themselves, so they are very hard to see. I wish JBL had made the L/R letters bigger or at least made them a different color so they would be easier to see.The pairing process was fairly easy with all my bluetooth-capable devices and the range was good, only dropping out after walking approximately 60-70 feet from the source. There was one momentary dropout during my listening but that could be due to my wife using her AirPods the same time as I was using the JBL's.I can't speak to the other features of the JBL Vibe Beams as I don't intend to use them, but as far as audio quality goes, with just a few minor tweaks, these bluetooth earbuds can go from sounding like a $50 pair of earbuds to a $500 pair of reference earphones.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States October 21, 2023

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Decent ear buds, but fit isn't exact and battery life is questionable
author: warren smith
content: I had to replace a set of headphones that stopped working. So this time I thought I would try a set of earbuds instead. I know JBL usually have good products, price was decent, so I thought I would try these.First I will say the sound and volume are pretty good. If you are using these on your phone, the JBL app also makes a big difference with the equalizer and the other "hear through" type features if you don't want to block out all noise. Really wish they had a similar app for PC, as I use them on my laptop more than my phone. And is really when I need to hear people talking etc.With that said, the fit isn't great, I tried all the different sizes of the rubber covers, but none seem to fit right in my left ear for some reason. I've had it fall out once already when just bending over to pick something up off the floor.They are also difficult to get out of the case, the lid should open further or just have a way to grab a hold of them easier.The battery life is ok, but doesn't seem to be anywhere near the 32 hours listed, including the recharge feature of the case. I've gotten about half that, before they kept telling me they were "low battery". And I had to charge them and the case both back up.all in all, these may work good for some people. I am thinking about returning them and trying something else though.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars excellent battery life. lots of good feature ideas that don't really work IRL.
author: Mavev
content: When i purchased these I didn't know about the touch controls features. so if you touch one of them it will pause what you are listening to or if you touch the other it can adjust the volume depending on where you tap it. it's very sensitive and I find anything that touches it, hair or hat will pause your podcast. You can turn this feature off with the app. The "find my buds" feature in the app for this is great in theory, but pretty useless in real life practice. (I lost one of them a week after owning them.) unless they are currently on and bluetooth connected to the phone with the app you can't make it ping the bud and make a sound to find it. so despite knowing where I lost the bud and knowing i was in range I couldn't find it. So i now have one earbud.The sound quality is good but the noise cancelling isn't capable of cancelling out a mower or a weed wacker enough for you to hear what you were listening to clearly. the pass through sound feature isn't really useful either, on this scale the mic quality just isn't good enough to do that and not have people sound like old robots. It does work.. it just makes everything sound like an old mono radio broadcast.The battery life is really the best feature of these buds. I can listen for 5 hours straight and not have to put it back on the charger. I only listen to podcasts on my single remaining ear bud, maybe if you listened to something with more bass it would drain faster. but for my purposes it's perfect. I also really like that the app shows you the remaining battery percentage of each bud

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Really good sound, but...
author: Customer
content: For a $50 pair of ear buds, these sound impressive. I've paid twice the price before and not been nearly this impressed. They bring a new clarity of sound to some albums in which I gave been previously disappointed, eg Clockwork Angels, which has always sounded muddy, even on my custom home sound system. My music tastes have a wide range; whether classical, big band jazz, prog rock, shoe gazer, etc, these buds really deliver for the price. With the app, there is good ability to adjust the sound and other settings, which is very nice, if not unique to JBL.However, there is one big caveat. With all the ear buds I have used over the years, I have never, EVER had such a pain-in-the-*$$ time getting these damn things out of their charging case!! They are stupidly hard to grasp-- they sit deep in the case, don't have a good way to grab them, and the lid very much is in the way of trying to get to them. If you buy these, know you have to be very careful and deliberate about removing them from the case or you will definitely drop them and ultimately ruin them. And if you have big fingers, seriously consider another product...unless you just get a kick out of being extremely frustrated.JBL, if you're listening (sorry for the pun), redesign the case so the ear buds rest in them 180 degrees from the way they do now, increase the surface area to pull them out, and please, PLEASE, redesign the case to have the lid flip farther back out of the way so that people with even average- sized fingers can get to these ear buds!

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Quality Earbuds with some Caveats
author: Noah & Brooke
content: These are great earbuds, especially when discounted. I feel it necessary to say I purchased these at 50% off, and for that price they are definitely worth it. At $100, I would definitely go for Samsung's or something similar.Here is the rundown.Pros:- Long battery life- Good noise cancelling, about 50-60%% effective or so (not as good as headphones obviously, but good)- Sleek design- Can adjust to stay in your ear pretty well- JBL app is available for Android at least, and allows you to easily manage and fine tune your audio experience which is greatCons:- get very uncomfortable after wearing for a while (could be the particular fit piece I use or way I'm wearing them, not sure, but it hurts after awhile)- noise cancelling, while good, is not amazing, and it causes noises outside to be kinda sharp and close-feeling (like someone yanking on your earbud cord back when earbuds were wired)Overall, great choice at $50. title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Low-end Offerings
author: NORMAN GARCIA
content: Purchased these JBL Tune Buds a few weeks ago as I had misplaced my Javbra 5 Buds and needed a quick and inexpensive replacement.Here are my observations:Fit - I am of average ear size (I think). I tried all three sizes of bud that came with the packaging. The medium size fit best but by best, I mean just adequate. The silicon buds were cheap feeling and lacked any stiffness that might have helped secure them better to my ear and helped/assisted the ANC when turned on.Active Noise Cancellation (ANC) - I live in a metropolitan area that is chronically loud. If you live in a quieter area, these might work for you. For me, the ANC is poor to adequate and I suspect the ill fitting bud plays into this factor.Software - I feel the software is mediocore at best. I use these buds for playing music and for remote meetings via MS TEAMs. Once the TEAMs meeting starts the software deactivates ANC and you are able to hear the "ambient' sounds from your surrounding environment. I can hear the meeting participants fine but they complain that they have trouble hearing me. They tell me that the barely hear my voice and instead hear the noise around me. Not sure of the logic making this "auto ANC off" for meetings a thing with the buds/software. Ultimately, I just listen and don't offer much feedback because it ends up being a distraction.Talk - On individual calls, friends and family hear me fine.Meetings - not recommended for meetings as the software is set to turn off ANC once a meeting begins.Gaming - I feel that young people could use these phones to game if they are in a quiet setting like their room.Price - I feel that these JBL Tune Buds were priced adequately around $50.Final Thoughts - If you are willing to pay $25 more I recommend Jabra 5 buds. Your ears will thank you for it.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Mastering Engineer Approved
author: Jenn
content: A lot of pros with one con.I didn‚Äôt think I had a lot of time for earbuds during the day, so I started off trying a cheap pair. They were $20 or something with 4.8 stars and reviews like, ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt used my Airpods since buying these!‚Äù so I thought that sounded perfect.They sucked. The sound was harsh, they became painful after extended use, noise cancelling was barely noticeable, etc. I can‚Äôt actually remember all of the problems at this point. BUT they sold me on the functionality of wireless headphones.Fast-forward to a few months later - it‚Äôs Black Friday and I bite on these because they‚Äôre on sale. I was a little hesitant because they had a lowly 4.2 stars. Turns out average reviews aren‚Äôt everything.These are the polar opposite of the highly-reviewed, cheap headphones I tried: they‚Äôre comfortable, and the sound is amazing. As the title implies, I master audio so this is not a hollow endorsement. The cheap ones had hyped bass, missing mids, and painful presence/treble. These are very flat and well-performing by comparison, and can be EQ‚Äôd. The noise cancelling is also VERY respectable. I frequently work around loud sources and am sensitive to loud noises, and I have accidentally left these in when I intended to swap for earplugs, because the performance is similar.I love the app. Being able to select between audio quality vs. video sync‚Äôing is awesome when I want to watch live musical performances where sync issues play with your mind. Being able to create custom EQ settings is very important to me too.The con is that you have to take them out of the case to power them on. It‚Äôs not a huge deal - it‚Äôs easy to pop them in for a split second if they‚Äôve timed out or something. But there has been one occasion that I ran somewhere and forgot the case. I intend to live my life without dependence on crap like headphones, so no big deal - take a break.I would normally give something like this 4 stars because that power-on function is a notable miscalculation on JBL‚Äôs part, but it deserves a much better average review than it has so I‚Äôm doing my part to raise it. In everyday life it‚Äôs not that big of a deal unless you‚Äôre the kind of person who loves to find things to complain about.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good earbuds, not fantastic
author: Frank
content: I use many different earbuds and headphones. These JBL Tune buds produce a good sound with my iPhone, especially when using the JBL app which has preset equalizer settings for different sounds and can deliver amazing base. Overall these are fairly good earbuds at a sale price of around $50. The box includes 3 pairs of silicon tips, small, medium and large, the silicon material is too smooth and too thin, they slide out easily and do not sit very securely for me, but this is very subjective and can be different for everyone. title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Fantastic sound, great battery life, a great buy!
author: TheRevenite
content: I bought these on the Black Friday sale and man, I'm so glad I did. I have several pairs of the lesser Vibes, which sound good, but these blow them out of the water.First, let's address the fitment. I see many say they don't fit, they fall out, or feel like they're going to fall out. Don't put the large ear pads on if you don't have large ear canal openings! This will cause the earbuds to push themselves out. Too large will push them out, while too small will obviously not have enough to grip your ear. Test them all to find the right fit, if not, reach out to JBL, I'm sure they have replacement pads of other sizes. You can also buy them here on Amazon as they're pretty universal.I find pushing them in, and turning them into place, with the proper pads, netted a great seal and no falling out.You HAVE to install the app on your phone; otherwise, you're getting the flat sound your phone manufacturer decided sounded good. The JBL app is available for Apple and Android - and it makes a massive difference, especially with the noise cancellation and frequency response.With these, I'm hearing songs I've listened to for decades for the first time. I'm hearing effects and instruments I never heard in the music. These are that clear. They also don't kill my ears! I've tried earbuds from $5 to $300, and while the more expensive ones sounded terrific, they hurt my ears physically. With these, I get great sound and a great fit with a tremendous battery life.I'm reading a lot of negative reviews where either the fit or the sound is the problem. Most of these would be positive if people were provided with either longer pads so they go a bit further into the ear and more sizes and those with sound complaints would actually install the app. Mine sounded horrible with the Dolby equalizer baked into Android 13. Installing the app AND turning off any phone equalizer or sound enhancer was the solution. I'd definitely buy these again!

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Finally found decent performing earbuds
author: Photographer
content: My standard for headphones is fairly high. I have a few pairs of high-end (also expensive) wired headphones for indoor, critical listening. I also have a pair of inexpensive earbuds for exercise. The sound quality is obviously subpar. I have been looking for a replacement.I bought and returned many over the last couple years; none lived up to my standard. Most of them had poor sound quality. I did buy one pair last year that was decent, but it had connection problems. So I returned it.I pretty much gave up until I came across this one. The price was too good to pass up. It was delivered not quickly, but within the promised time frame. Given my experience, I have low expectations. But the JBL brand name does give me some hope of acceptable quality.BT Connection was fast and secure with no problems so far. Sound quality is much better than I expected, especially for the price. While the sound stage is not as open as my high-end wired headphones, imagining is excellent, which I did not expect. Tonal balance is also excellent with no treble fatigue or excessive bass; I set the equalizer to neutral flat. I can wear it for prolong periods. I like it enough to wear it while moving around the house.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Wanted to really like these
author: Jason
content: Pros:Reputation Brand NameGood sound with JBL Headphone appPlenty of bass with JBL Headphone appCONS:FitBluetooth disconnectsI purchased these after mt galaxy bud 2 died, due to one bud falling out into my pool last year then finally died about a month ago.My primary use for ear buds is listening to music while doing yard work (mowing, weed eating, edging) and during pool maintenance (brushing the walls and vacuuming).When I first received these, I downloaded the app and they paired nicely with no issues. Capsule charge was at 75% while both buds were at 100%.Next I tried placing them in my ears. When i placed them in my ears and turn them counterclockwise the weren't very comfortable and felt loose like they were going to fall out, however they did say in place when i tilted my head to either side and shook my head. These earbuds are supplied additional ear cushions. I tried the bigger ones and for my ears these were too big for my ear canal and would not stay in very well. I tried the smaller ones and these wouldn't hold in place. I'd like to say they were like Goldilocks and the 3 bears, but none were just right. The closest for me were the medium size, but I still didn't trust them staying in while doing yard work.Today was the first day I've had to really put them to the test. I place them in and fiddle with them for a bit to get a "snug" fit. The only way I could achieve this was by turning them so that the J in the JBL logo was at about a 180 degrees facing upwards.I started Spotify and proceeded to start the yard work. I noticed myself constantly fiddling with the earbud, because the kept feeling like the were going to fall out, enough so that I kept activating the voice pass through.After about a hour and a half into the yard work I was met with a bluetooth disconnected message. When I looked at my phone (Samsung galaxy s23 ultra) it showed bluetooth was enabled and the buds were paired. I started Spotify again and the music resumed. So I was like ok????I did about another 2 hrs of yard work and they stayed connected, but I still constantly felt they were going to fall out.With today's experience, I will not be using these near my poolWould I recommend these to a friend? Probably notDo i think these were worth what I paid for them? No, with the fit issue, these should cost closer to $19.99

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Not as good as expected, lost one within a week.
author: Michael and Karrie
content: Don't get me wrong, these are decent earphones. On par with the good sounding off brand $30 sets. Big difference is that they have features that help with ambient sounds and has noise canceling. Thing though is I was very unimpressed with those features after owning a pair of Bose earphones. These were also really lightweight/cheap feeling compared to my Bose, and weren't as easy to use with the taps and stuff. Then there is the fitment issues. Do they have different size rubber pieces? Yes. 3 sizes, 1 set of each. None of them worked, to the point that almost every facial muscle movement or jaw movement caused them to fall out. Personally I like to be able to talk when I'm on a phone call, but these made it hard to. And trying to watch a movie while eating? Impossible! I spent more time catching/picking up my earbud and trying to resume the movie than I did eating.Ultimately my advice is that if you're not wanting to spend a lot of money on features like noise cancelation, take a chance with an off brand for a third of the price and you'll most likely still have the same sound quality. If you want thise features and are willing to pay this price, spend a little more and get Bose or a good brand that knows how to to it right. If you want them to stay in your ears, go with literally ANYTHING else!Battery life was great though!

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Excellent for the price, controls are finicky
author: Cameron Wylie
content: Good sound quality, battery life, and noise isolation for a very affordable price. It's shocking to take the headphones off and realize how loud everything is going on around you, even in a relatively quiet spot. They fit really well and comfortable in my ears, which is unusual as my ear canals are somewhat narrow. They provide multiple plugs to find the right fit for you.You have to download the Samsung wearable app to have full control over them, which is a little annoying. It took a while to make a connection and I was wondering if I would have to return them. I think restarting my phone did the trick. Galaxy s22.The touch controls are a bit annoying and limited compared to other Samsung headphones I've owned. They do not have swipe gesture to control volume. I use these while working out, so I turn off touch controls altogether to prevent changing volume or stopping my music while I'm moving around. For normal everyday use, they are probably fine for most people.Overall, for the price, hard to beat.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Love them
author: Lora Singleton
content: For years I used the cheap neckband style of Bluetooth earbuds, and when I decided a while back to switch to actual earbuds, I tried at least 3 or 4 brands and styles and couldn't find ones that didn't KILL my ears. IDK if my ears are weirdly-shaped or what, but I tried TOZO NC2s and JLab Go Air Pops which both were incredibly painful. I also tried a friend's Airpods briefly and they also hurt. Finally I spotted a relative's Galaxy Buds 2 and asked to try them and the difference was incredible - these are super comfortable!The sound quality is also incredible compared to all others I've tried, and while I've never really bothered with ANC on other ones I've tried, the noise cancelling on these is certainly good enough for me. I do tend to leave it off to save the battery though, which is the main weak point of these. 5 1/2 hours or so with noise cancelling on isn't great. But I find they block enough noise for me even with it off, which makes the battery life more like 8 hours or a bit over. Even with ANC off, they block enough that I can't hear someone across the room trying to get my attention unless they're really yelling. I often use just one earbud, and I like that you can use either on its own and easily switch between them.I have a Samsung phone, which means the Galaxy Wear app lets you manage these and use the equalizer settings and such. I also love the fast pair with Samsung, where they pop up immediately asking to pair or connect, and I REALLY like the seamless pairing feature that lets me switch them instantly between my phone and my (Windows) computer without have to go into Bluetooth settings and disconnect or unpair from one to pair to the other.Overall, very happy with these. I wasn't sure how much I would really use them, so was hesitant to pay the full retail price, and the first refurbished pair I tried had one earbud that didn't work which made me wary of going that route. So this international version seemed like a nice option. I added an Asurion protection plan just in case, but so far these have worked flawlessly for several months.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States November 3, 2022

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great product for the price
author: JJohn
content: Great buds.Had so many issues with the Sennheiser CX True Wireless. Consant dropouts and having to factory reset every other week.Galaxy is so much better. Just plug and play.It might install some type of Galaxy Wearable app but you can just uninstall it. One trick is once you've paired the buds and stow they away. Turn on Phone Bluetooth then pull the buds out of the case, it'll reconnect on it's own and not have to bother with the Galaxy Wearable app screen. Or just double click back button on Android if you pair the regular way.Sound is incredible for $65, it won't knock your socks off but it surpasses it's price point. Also doesn't overwhelm you with bass like most earphones. Loud bass doesn't indicate good quality and I appreciate that Samsung agrees with that. Supposedly ANC only works when both buds are used but I've had luck on a single earbud. Pretty much can't hear noise on my left ear.Be careful using both buds on ANC when walking or crossing. It really does work well, maybe too well.Buds are comfortable even good enough for side sleepers on a firm pillow.Haven't tested the battery properly as I only use it for commute for about an hour. Usually only need to charge the case once every 10 days. ANC will increase drain on the battery if activated.Overall really great buds for $65. Can't complain much and even the annoying app install can be removed or simply backed out by a couple presses of the back button. I've had more annoying earbuds before. I appreciate the quality and price Samsung offers for this product.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States October 16, 2023

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Truly Impressive!
author: Trey Brown
content: Purchased these when they were on sale and was completely blown away!First thing that stood out was the active noise cancellation! Being able to go from noise cancellation to ambient sounds is great, especially for certain situations!If you're in a loud environment and want to listen to music/audio books - noise cancellation! If you want to listen to music but need to be aware of your surroundings and hear people - ambient sounds! The noise cancellation blocks out roughly 80-90% of the total outside sound; its amazing! The ambient sounds option plays back your voice in the earbuds, so that you're not yelling at people next to you, you'll maintain your normal talking voice.As for the quality of sound - they're good! Nothing truly stands out here, but they have a good sound quality and there isn't too much bass/treble.Battery life is good! You'll get several hours of play time before needing to put them back in the case. Out of a full charge on the case, I can go about 2-3 days before needing to charge the case again.My advice to those that purchase - you get much more access to different options and controls if you download the Samsung Wearable app, which gives these earbuds even more appeal! Even if I didn't get these during a sale, they'd still 100% be worth the price!
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 30, 2023

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Love these ear buds

content: So far they are the best buds for allowing ambient sound through when you need to hear and have an excellent microphone so when talking on a call you are heard well. The sound is very good and can link with phone, TV, or any Bluetooth item effortly.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 24, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Just like brand new
author: Micah K
content: I had a pair of knock-off Galaxy Buds, and the design was similar, but they had no ANC at all (even though the packaging hyped it up--it just didn't exist). The sound quality from them was barely acceptable--I didn't expect much from some cheap knock-offs.I have purchased renewed products before, and I know that sometimes it's a crap-shoot---you may get something that isn't any good. I was willing to take that chance for some decent ear buds.When I got them, they still had a bit of charge, so I was eager to try them. I opened up the case, and my phone (Samsung) immediately detected them and assigned them a name. I put one in my ear and music from Spotify started playing. I got the other one in, and was immediately surprised at the depth and richness of the sound. The knock off pair didn't really have a lot of bass, but these Buds 2 really delivered (compared to the knockoffs).That's not to say that they have an amazing sound, but when you listen to Chinese fakes, the difference is staggering.Battery life is not as long as I would like--I get about 5 hours with ANC on, so it's not terrible, I just wish it was a bit longer---not that I have reason to have them in my ears for longer than that (well, except on plane rides). The case doesn't take too long to top them off, but I haven't tested to see how many charges I can get out of the case.They are comfortable enough to sleep with them in my ears. I have taken a few naps with them in my ears listening to some soft music and the ANC on, and have not been awakened by the neighbor's dogs--they are worth the price for that alone.I've very satisfied with this purchase.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 13, 2023

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars A good deal... at half price.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars My first wireless earbuds
author: Rush
content: I didn't want to write this review until I had a lot of time with these earphones. After weeks of rigerous use and while working (delivering for Amazon), I have a solid opinion on this product.I wanted to be able to listen to music and talk on the phone while on the go or at work but isn't really possible with wired earphones. These Galaxy Buds 2 are a great option but definitely not perfect.The sound quality of the buds 2 are great but if you don't keep them clean, the sound quality goes down. The battery life of the buds and case are quite impressive. I use only 1 bud at a time which each lasts me about 4 hours while the case can last about 16 hours on a full charge. The ambient and noise canceling features are great too but the ambient sound feature can get too noisy if it's windy or a lot of stuff going on in the background. The phone quality is good but sometimes the person I'm on call with has trouble hearing me if I'm moving around or there's too much background sound (which is usually the case while I'm delivering) but still works okay so don't expect the best quality with phone calls. I also love the wireless charging feature.Overall this has been one of my best purchases of the year as I definitely have gotten my money's worth and enjoyment out of this product. If this'll be your first wireless earbuds, just give these a try!

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent sound. Nifty bells and whistles that shorten battery life. User friendliness is iffy
author: Z.K.
content: The earbuds overall are wonderful. The sound is crisp and clear. I was hesitant after seeing some reviews mentioning discomfort and the earbuds easily falling out. I've used these all day every workday for seventeen days. I've fallen asleep with these things in my ears at night. I can say that I've had no issues with these things falling out. Quite the contrary. With the larger bud tips (don't remember the exact name for 'em) these earbuds have stayed in my ears without issue. In fact, I'd say, when it comes to staying in, these earbuds are more reliable than any other earbuds I've had. They've stayed in through walking, running, exercise, tossing and turning in my sleep, you name it!Now these earbuds do have a few bells and whistles that eat into the battery life. Of all the earbuds I've had, these ones definitely have the worst battery life. However, that's not really saying much. The extensive battery lives of most wireless earbuds have set that bar very high. And while these particular earbuds didn't quite clear that bar, the battery life is still more than adequate for me. I've never had issues with these things running out of juice on me. After four hours of near consistent use without recharging, the battery was still at 54 percent.In any case, the tradeoff is worth it for me. I'm loving the active noise cancellation as well as the ambient sound mode. It's so nice to be able to listen to someone without having to take out one earbud and hold it in your hand. Incidentally, I realized I could use ambient sound mode to filter out annoying sounds while listening to someone. For example, with ambient sound at medium volume, I could hear the voices of my peers just fine, but I didn't hear the annoying hum of florescent lights.The earbuds may not be the most user friendly. There aren't really instructions that come with it. Just a QR code directing you to download the app. The app will then instruct you on how to use these. You do need to download the app to get these things working. It did trip me up at the beginning but once I figured it out, I actually grew to like the app. The app lets you control the ambient noise volume, locate your earbuds if you misplace them, and disable touch controls so you don't accidentally pause or play whatever you're listening to. There is an app available for windows computers (don't know about macs). I use these on my pc as well as my android phone.All in all, I'm happy with my purchase. If you don't mind trading off some battery life for some nifty features, and don't mind having to add an app to your phone to get your earbuds going, then I would highly recommend these
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 22, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Best Earbuds I've used, with some downsides
author: A
content: These are the best earbuds I've used so far. I used a set of akg n400's before, but they were way too uncomfortable, fell out too easily, and battery life sucked. That could just be me and the fact I didn't have the other silicone ear triangle things. Not sure these sound as good as the n400's, but they sound very good.Sound:I like good audio, but I really don't have a great ear for judging quality. That said, these sound great to me. They sound very similiar to the AKG N400's perhaps with less bass.Fit:The buds2 fit in my ear very nicely with the included tips and I can wear them for around 9hrs without issues. They do fall out occasionall, but it's usually easy to feel when they're falling out and adjust them.Battery:The battery life on these is very impressive, as they often last 6-9hrs without charging in the case. For some reason the earbuds often drain their batteries unevenly, so you'll end up with one dead and one with 20-30% charge still. The case battery is very good and I've never ran it empty before.Case:Honestly, the case is probably my biggest issue with these earbuds. Any light drop and the case will shoot out the tiny earbuds in a 360, and then the case will close itself. This makes it really easy to lose the earbuds and not notice because the case closed itself back up.Buttons: It took me a few weeks of using the earbuds to appreciate the touch controls. Now it works fairly reliably. The app also gives you a lot of controls for the buttons.Noise Cancellation/Ambient Sound: Noise cancelling is pretty good. Not amazing but good. Some static is audible when using it. Ambient sound is okayish. It picks up on a lot of unwanted background noises like fan noise and doesn't pick up on people's speech well. Both of these features are made worse by what I talk about below.Other issues. Perhaps the most annoying issue is the earbuds have some sensor that detects if the earbud is in your ear. If it detects one earbud is not in your ear, it will disable noise cancelling or ambient sound until it detects them in your ear again. It's a great idea but it malfunctions all the time if the earbuds aren't perfectly seated in your ear. Meaning you'll be adjusting them a lot if you use noise cancelling or ambient sound. The app seriously some spyware. I've never seen any app ask for more permissions and it won't open if you deny most of them. I recommend you have some way to trick the app to deny permissions if you care about privacy. The main permissions you want to deny is location or it's ability to connect to the internet if your phone can do that, unless you need its find my earbuds ability. Otherwise the app is pretty useful and leagues better than the AKG app.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States January 1, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Samsung strikes again! Quality, affordable, Bluetooth earbuds.
author: Alex Gonzalez
content: The Galaxy Buds 2 are good quality Bluetooth earbuds. Having owned the Galaxy Buds+ originally, these were a decent upgrade in some regards and a downgrade in others.**Comfort**Probably the most important aspect of earbuds for some people is the comfort quality. The earbuds include 3 different size ear tips to help you find the right fit. Additionally, in the Galaxy Wearable app, there is a feature to actually test the fit. This is helpful as you can tinker and find the right earbud tip combinations for you. Prolonged sessions did result in some ear fatigue for me and I found the tips becoming a bit loose with excessive movement. I would probably not wear these to work out in. My aforementioned Galaxy Buds+ have wingtips on the top that help them remain securely in place, I find them to be a bit more comfortable than these.**Battery Life**Battery life on the Galaxy Buds 2 appear to be as advertised. For my use they are perfect as I do not wear my buds for long periods of time and am able to charge them in between sessions easily. The included charging case is easy to use and I can snap the buds in with no issues. Again, the Galaxy Buds+ were a bit better in this regard with the battery lasting around 9 hours on one charge, but they also did not have Active Noise Cancellation which consumes a good amount of battery life.**Connectivity**Using a Galaxy phone makes connecting these headphones a breeze! It was a simple as opening the case. Seriously, once I did that my phone recognized it and had a popup to pair. Connecting them to my tablet (S8) was not as easy. I had to put the earbuds into pairing mode and open my Galaxy Wearable app on the tablet and connect that way. Once set up, it is very easy to reconnect. I also was able to pair with my Chromecast for late night TV viewing without waking up my wife.**Audio**This is where this set of earbuds earns its keep in my opinion. I am by NO MEANS an audiophile but the audio quality coming from the Buds+ was night and day for me. Music, TV, and calls all sound clear and crisp with a decent amount of bass without virtually 0 static. The ambient noise and active noise cancellation features work as intended and the 360 audio is a very cool feature to add a level of immersion, especially when watching movies.**Conclusion**This is a solid set of earbuds and at the current price point, makes a ton of sense in my opinion. I am very pleased with this set and will continue to use them as my "daily driver" earbuds.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great wireless earbuds for the price.
author: Kenton
content: I'm going to do a pros and cons list to make this alot simpler, and so you can easily find what you would like to know.Pros:1. Overall great sound quality, no complaints really, and there is a eq app that allows you to customize the sound to your preference. Whether that be if you like more bass or a soft listening experience.2. Comfort is good on these earbuds, genuinely some of the most comfortable earbuds out there. And they come with different sized ear pieces. But comfort is subjective so your mileage may vary.3. Battery life is great, I very rarely need to charge them. You can definitely get 6 hours out of them on a full charge. And the case can store an additional 15 hours. It takes 15 min to charge the earbuds to full and 2 hours to charge the case to full.Cons:1. Noise cancelation is not great. Don't be expecting to jump on a plane and drown out the engine, talking, and inevitable crying baby. The anc is like a 4/102. If you don't have a samsung phone it will not be as seamless of an experience. Meaning widgets won't display battery percentage, you also won't get a pop up when connected telling you battery percentage. You won't be able to change eq settings either since the app you need is only on samsung devices. So my advice is to get the respected earbuds that pair with your phone. So, if you have a iPhone, get airpods. If you have a pixel, get pixel buds. Etc.3. Minor nit-pick but sometimes my earbuds will randomly disconnect, so I will have to put them back in the case and then put them back in my ears.4. The touch controls aren't very good. They aren't very responsive, So don't bother with them.Overall they are extremely good earbuds for the price. They are a great budget option for wireless earbuds that will surely not disappoint. And if you have Samsung phone they are even better, with all the features you gain by staying in the samsung ecosystem.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars No regrets, will buy again if needed.
author: Keekee
content: This is the second pair of wireless earbuds that I've owned, but the first one that I bought.I've had them for 4 months at this point.‚úì The most important feature for me was the comfort of the buds. Most earbuds make my ears sore after any use longer than half an hour. I can wear these for hours at a time for days in a row if I want to.‚úì The noise canceling feature was also important for me. Even when they aren't in active noise canceling mode, I can't hear my partner (who has a deep and booming voice that's known to travel) when they're in the next room with the door open.‚úì The charging case can seem like it takes a while to fully charge, but I feel like it's worth it due to how long it stays charged and how many uses I can get from it.‚úì The sound quality is the best I've experienced from any headphone or earbud (not that I've tried a lot). The sound is clear, and I don't need to have my media up ridiculously high just to hear it anymore.‚úì The buds are magnetically pulled into their ports but aren't difficult to remove.‚úì It's perfect for traveling. The case is compact and the cord is short and comes in a little box to keep it organized.‚úó The case is sleek. I dropped it within seconds of picking it up out of the box because it slipped right out of my fingers.‚úó I was under the impression that I wouldn't need to install the app to use the different functions of the earbuds. It could be that I just haven't figured it out, but any time I try to delete the app, I have issues with getting the earbuds to work properly.‚úó Initially, I was impressed that these buds stayed in my ears as I went about my business, but it's gotten to a point where I do have to be mindful when they're in. If I smile too widely, they pop out. If I turn my head too fast or look up and to the side, they pop out. Sometimes they'll pop out when I bend to pick things up.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good buds!
author: David D
content: I recently purchased the SAMSUNG Galaxy Buds FE True Wireless Bluetooth Earbuds in the Graphite color and I have been extremely impressed with their performance. As someone who is always on the go and constantly listening to music or podcasts, having a reliable and comfortable pair of earbuds is essential for me. The Galaxy Buds FE have exceeded my expectations in both of these areas.First and foremost, the comfort and secure fit of these earbuds is top-notch. The wing-tip design ensures that they stay in place even during intense workouts or when I'm running errands. I have tried many other wireless earbuds in the past and have always struggled with finding a pair that stays in my ears comfortably. The Galaxy Buds FE have solved this problem for me and I can wear them for hours without any discomfort.The sound quality of these earbuds is also impressive. The audio is clear and crisp, with a good balance of bass and treble. I have used them for both music and phone calls and have been pleased with the sound in both scenarios. The touch controls on the earbuds are also very convenient and easy to use. I can easily pause or skip a song without having to take out my phone.One of the standout features of these earbuds is the auto switch audio. This allows me to seamlessly switch between my phone and laptop when I receive a call or want to listen to something on my computer. It's a small feature, but it has made a big difference in my daily routine.I also appreciate the built-in voice assistant feature. I can easily access my virtual assistant with just a touch of the earbud, making it convenient to make calls, send texts, or get directions without having to take out my phone.The battery life on these earbuds is also impressive. I can use them for several hours without needing to recharge, and the charging case provides additional battery life when I'm on the go. The case is also compact and easy to carry around.Overall, I highly recommend the SAMSUNG Galaxy Buds FE True Wireless Bluetooth Earbuds. They offer a comfortable and secure fit, great sound quality, and convenient features that make them a must-have for anyone looking for a reliable pair of wireless earbuds. Whether you're a music lover, fitness enthusiast, or just someone who wants a hassle-free listening experience, these earbuds are definitely worth considering.The only drawback is that the case is not wireless charging. Losing the one star.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars No Way

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Better to buy new and Best with Samsung phone
author: Julie
content: This is a bit long but I feel it provides good info regarding your phone or electronic device to be paired with earbuds and purchasing new vs used earbuds. If you have questions about these topics please read!I purchased these for my boyfriend. He has a Samsung S22. I have bought him multiple types of brand new earbuds in the $70-$80 range in the past. He had to charge all those daily in order to used for 1.5 hrs while he walked. I wanted to buy him something nicer so I bought these. I chose to buy a used set in hopes that they were in great condition and maybe the box was just torn. I changed them overnight on accident (I prefer not to charge too long). Then paired then with my iPhone. I have owned several versions and pairs of iPods and Beats Pro (over the ear). So my first reaction was disappointment because the sound quality did not compare and little things didn‚Äôt work the same. For example when you take your Beats out if your ear whatever your watching stops. That is not the case with these. Also when a call comes in, I had to manually change the option to the ear bud on my phone screen vs just answering by touching my ear. However, I still gave them to my boyfriend for Easter and when he paired them with his galaxy he was prompted to add an extra app that gave him different features than I had with my Apple. Initially he was not too impressed with the sound, he expected them to be louder. The noise canceling was so good, he had to take them out to hear me talk to him. What he loved about them was the length of time he was able to go before charging the case. Remember I charged them one time, then he used them off of my original charge after sitting in the box for a few days. He wore them everyday for 5 days without charging the case. At that point he was really happy with them. Enough to overlook the sound quality since it was not what he expected. Unfortunately when he charged the case he was not able to get the Right earbud to charge. We tried different troubleshooting methods. Unfortunately none of them have worked. We will be sending them back. I don‚Äôt have experience using Apple headphones or buds with Samsung phones but I feel if I had bought these brand new, he would keep them vs buying headphones like mine. I‚Äôd rather pay an extra $50 to get new products going forward. Please air on the side of caution if you buy used or refurbished version of these ear buds. Hopefully this helps someone trying to decide between new or used and Apple/Beats products vs Other earbuds to pair with an android phone.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Not overly impressed
author: Amazon Cutstomer
content: I've only had these a day but there are not many reviews so I'll give my 1st impressions. I wore them for a few hours doing yard work (using my Samsung S22) and tried them with some of my favorite test tracks connected to my PC and using Amazon HD music (using Exclusive mode)The first thing that surprised me was the white case... I ordered black, and at first thought they sent the wrong ones but opened the case and the buds themselves were black. I don't like white, but whatever.Looking at the case there is not much indication of what is the front and it's a bit fiddly to open. The magnet to suck the buds into place is not very strong, so a bit fiddly to lay them in the case.I don't like wearing buds much, but these were pretty comfortable right out of the box. The insertion was not quite as deep as I like but they stayed in well while I was moving around and I did not feel the need to keep adjusting them.How do they sound:I want to emphasize these are first impressions.These have a polite sound that would probably please many people. I'm not one of them. When I got the Lypertek buds for the same price I told people "I can't believe how good a sound you can get for $100 these days". With these, I would say "They are ok, most people would like them".They are "fine" for having something playing in your ear while you do something else but they did not bring out any joy in the music for me. Nothing stood out about the sound. Ordinary comes to mind or, nothing wrong but nothing right. I'm not into 'soundstage' the the lack of one while listening to live tracks actually stood out to me.The sound is a bit congested, the instruments kind of bunched into each other. There is no 'air' around the instruments. I found myself pushing the volume louder than I normally listen to "wake them up a bit".Detail retrieval is decent, but you are not going to notice the reverb, the grind of a distorted guitar, the 'ting' of the drumsticks on a cymbal, breath sounds, etc. The overall presentation is smooth enough from low to high, with no glaring holes, or peaks. If I had to fault the frequency response it would be male voices. Just a bit in your face at times. Bass get a bit tubby if you try to push it much. In "normal" mode I found it just about right.Let's see what I can 'fix' with EQ. The EQ in the App has 9 bands, cool! But that hardly matters if there is no custom EQ option. Seriously Samsung? The Sennheiser App only has 3 bands but at least they let you set a custom EQ, name it, and save it.There are 7 presets, but none of them really gave me something I liked. But there is enough variety that most people would find something they like.I'm mixed on keeping them. The sound is good enough for what I want them for. listening to music while I do something else. They are comfortable and stay in well, but I am not impressed with the sound. It's "fine", it's "okay", and "good enough" but not impressed with the sound for the $100 price point.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States October 21, 2023

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good BT earbuds
author: Photographer
content: I generally prefer over the ear headphones, but I use earbuds only when I am exercising or doing yardwork. I bought a pair of name brand earbuds that was on sale during BF. Long story short, I had to return it because the sound quality was unacceptable.Rather than trying to find a diamond in haystack so to speak, I picked Sennheiser as it is a brand that I have good experience with. Furthermore, I opted for a higher price point than the rock bottom price I was hoping for.I forgo noise cancelling since I don't need it most of the time. Sonically, this pair of earbuds is very good, bearing typical Sennheiser sound of open and balance. It is still no match for my over the ear headphones, but it is also significantly cheaper. Sound quality is by far the most important aspect, other features are distant seconds and thirds.BT connectivity is, however, not Sennheiser's strength. It took some work to get it connected to all of my devices; I have a pair of Sennheiser over the ear BT headphone that behaves similarly. All of my cheaper BT earbuds have no BT connectivity issues. This weakness is not a showstopper.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Sennheiser knows headphones
author: Baron
content: I had some Klipsch ear pods I had to return. Sure they had the metal case and metallic earbuds and all those sizes earbud tips but internal quality was bad a constant buzzing sound from a bad chip so I ordered a second pair still bad so returned both of them. I started think what headphones do I she that just simply worked no gimmicks no flash just pure bonafide Hi-Fi then j realized Sennheiser of course. When I bought these they had just come out no Amazon reviews but I took the chance cause I love my HD-25s and I haven‚Äôt looked back. I‚Äôm an engineer a job that requires focus by my office is smack dab in the middle of a factory floor full of loud noise forklifts , bulldozers firing up for test, people grinding metal , all of that on top of the normal office chatter and these headphones cut right through that while I work at my desk and get work done.Now yes these are 100% plastic but they don‚Äôt feel cheap and that plastic also means they don‚Äôt feel cold touching your skinYes they use standard ear bud tips which I was apprehensive about cause I‚Äôve had issue with those falling off or coming off in my ear but these are designed with an aggressive ridge to keep the tips attached to the headphone.No wireless charging but who cares it‚Äôs USB-C just plug it in at night and go about your day they last all my work dayAnd the sound is probably as good as it gets from reasonably priced Bluetooth earbuds so yeah no bass boomy but that‚Äôs inherent in the form factor bass requires big drivers and lots of power which kills your battery life and adds weight.Could you get better sound sure but why it‚Äôs Bluetooth off your phone into tiny battery powered earbuds so your quality is limited already so this is probably that sweet spot where diminishing marginal returns kicks in where you have to spend way more money or buy big Bluetooth headphones to get better soundIf you buy these as earbuds for work or travel where portability and battery life trumps fidelity then you‚Äôll love these if you expect fidelity similar to much pricier wired headphones you‚Äôll be disappointed but only because your expectations were unrealistic.0

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Comprehensive rating: Sennheiser puts sound first (as usual)
author: Scott Herron
content: After years of using cheap-o headphones and dealing with cable noise, listening to music with the headphones feels like i'm hearing each song for the very first time. I'm hearing details in songs I never heard before, it honestly made me tear up. Incredibly clarity, customizable EQ, AMAZING sound for 100$. You could easily get something with comparable sound that costs twice as much. The sound is why I bought these. Sennheiser is a sound-focused brand. However, there are some places where these headphones cut corners that would not be a problem if you bought 200$+ dollar headphones.Security: I'm a dancer, and I want my headphones to stay on while I'm working in the studio. However, the earbuds aren't the most secure in my ears. They fly out during chain√©e turns, sometimes even just as I'm walking they'll fall out.Comfort: Not the most comfortable for hours of listening. After 2-3 hours of extended use, my ears ached. Changing up the plastic tips didn't help.Noise cancelling: I heard the ANC takes the edge off the sound quality, which is why I bought these and not the active noise cancelling ones. You can definitely tell. I can hear each step I take as I walk thudding in my ears. It's a little odd.Delay: I've tried to use these to watch tiktoks on my phone, and I've noticed a delay in the screen and the sound. I can see the person on my screen moving their mouth, but the words come out into my headphones a little later. It's not the worst, but it's noticeable.Overall: Great for audiophiles on a budget. The app allows you to customize, so there's something to love for everyone, whether you love a sparkling, bright treble or you're a total basshead. For sitting down and listening while you're at your computer, these are an excellent choice. If you're mainly wearing these for working out, maybe something else would suit your needs better. I do equal parts both, which is why I like these a lot. mp3 files can massacre the music quality, and bad headphones can make the sound even muddier. These are an excellent buy. I've had them for about a month, will update if something changes or I have issues.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Great sound quality, hounded by connectivity/app issues
author: Eric Notmyrealname
content: Great sound quality, hounded by electronics/connectivity issuesI‚Äôd give this 3.5 stars if I could. Having owned multiple headphones/earphones over the years this is product is in-line with Sennheiser ‚Äì great sound quality for the price (they lowered it), but you pay with electronics/wiring issues. This maybe the last Sennheiser product I get for a while, but not in a good way‚Ä¶Goal: Portable ‚Äúdo everything‚Äù earphones with good sound quality. I wanted to be able use them around the home: smartphone music, binging Netflix, work computer for Zoom calls, etc. I‚Äôd been using whatever generic thing $40 could get; this time I decided to splurge past $100 (purchased at was $130 w/ points).Pros:‚Ä¢ Sound quality. I‚Äôm not an audiophile, but I‚Äôve owned 10+ headphones/earphones, different brands. The sound is lively, bass is strong without being overwhelming.‚Ä¢ Case ‚Äì form factor is great! Fits in my pocket, doesn‚Äôt looks scuffed after many months of use.‚Ä¢ Battery life ‚Äì lasts for many hours before needing a charge. Could probably use it 2-3 days of regular use before getting a warning.‚Ä¢ Mic works ‚Äì gets the job done.‚Ä¢ Sennheiser app ‚Äì you can change what device it connects to and adjust EQ settings.Cons:‚Ä¢ Connectivity: atrocious. I‚Äôve had to soft reset / hard reset this too many times. Bluetooth isn‚Äôt a new technology. This should be ‚Äúset it and forget it.‚Äù * About 5% of the time, only 1 earphone connects. Disconnecting and reconnecting doesn‚Äôt do anything and I have to do a soft reset. * When using the app, it sometimes refuses to disconnect from the current device so I can connect to what the device I want. Real fun 3 minutes before your Zoom meeting! * Sometimes doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúremember‚Äù how to connect to specific device(s). I‚Äôve had to delete all pairings and reestablish connections twice so far in 9 months.‚Ä¢ App: clunky. Randomly asks to update the firmware ‚Äì no, Sennheiser! When I open this app, 99% of the time I want to switch devices! Do it right the first time!‚Ä¢ Features: this thing lacks soooo many features that exist on $40 earphones today. For this product not to have things like wireless charging, noise cancellation, connecting to multiple devices, the only thing I can think of is a paywall (greed: wanting to upsell a more expensive product).
